column1: Will Ethiopia be under a state of emergency as of 1 May 2017?
column5: ['Yes, nationwide', 'Yes, but only in some areas', 'No']
column6: ['Foreign Policy', 'Security and Conflict']
column11: In response to more than a year of protests, Ethiopia declared a six-month nationwide state of emergency on 8 October 2016 (Al Jazeera). Confused? Check our FAQ or ask us for help.

column6: Extended by four months back in March
Updating forecast.
The state of emergency has been extended by 4 months as of 30 March
The state of emergency has been extended for another four months.
Consolidate power and remove opposition under the banner of national security. This seems to be a successful model for governments in the 21st century.

As per @matthewenderlein It seems that the national State of Emergency has been renewed for another 4 months, but in some areas it is being applied differently. I far as I can see all areas are under the state of emergency, and the state of emergency law allows the government to then apply it as it thinks appropriate. As long as the government is not required to return to parliament in order to vary how they apply the law, I think this counts as "nationwide". https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/despite-outward-calm-ethiopia-extends-state-of-emergency/2017/03/30/b5544098-1529-11e7-ada0-1489b735b3a3_story.html?utm_term=.f66941edd833

Yes, nationwide: The Ethiopian Parliament approved a four month extension of the emergency on 30MAR17, no further governmental action is required to satisfy this condition. The parliament is dominated by the majority party (501 of 547 seats) and an extension approval requires only 2/3 majority (365/547). Furthermore, the easement of some of the more extreme restrictions brought about by the state of emergency makes the situation more tenable into the future. In short, the federal government has little incentive to remove the state of emergency, as it grants them extra powers to limit the ethnic federalist system and essentially remove the secession option by threat/use of force. Yes, but only in some areas: This condition would require state governments to independently declare states of emergency. Within the Ethiopian ethnic federalist system, these state governments are ethnically dominated and, in the case of Oromia, the government is dominated by the ethnic group which is staging the greatest opposition to the federal government. There is little incentive for the Oromian government to do this, as the opposition is a powerful tool in maintaining the ethnic balance of power at the federal level. No: To satisfy this condition, the Ethiopian Parliament would have to vote to remove the state of emergency within the month. This is unlikely because the federal government has no incentive to do this and is receiving very little international pressure (reduced after the initial rounds of arrests in OCT16) to do so. The most likely source of this outcome would be international pressure mounting from a future event that is a significant violation of human rights. Sources: http://www.africa.upenn.edu/Hornet/Ethiopian_Constitution.html http://www.aljazeera.com/news/2017/03/ethiopia-extends-state-emergency-months-170330110807086.html http://www.africanews.com/2017/03/15/ethiopia-relaxes-state-of-emergency-restrictions// https://www.justice.gov/eoir/page/file/916611/download

Oromo areas had been under state of emergency for a year before the 2016 nationwide, so the government is in no hurry to end states of emergency. However, there is an additional but not recorded option: the government lifts the state of emergency in name only in order to please the aid-giving nations while still carrying on with the policies brought in under the October decree.

Ethiopia is a tense country at the moment and the factors that drove the initial state of emergency (Oromo unhappiness and oppression) hasn't gone away. While the government has for the moment calmed the situation and detained (a wonderful euphemism) 20,000 people, the country is not run by fools and they must know they are merely keeping a lid of protests, not resolving the underlying problem. That is a recipe for keeping the state of emergency going.

A six month state of emergency has been in place since October 2016. So far, hundreds of people have been killed and thousands have been placed in jail by the governments security forces (Human Rights Watch, 2016). The Prime Minister has been in place since 2012 and it is difficult to imagine that nation/certain regions will be back under control to not extend the state of emergency by May 2017. Lastly, it was reported in December 2016 the economic growth declines to 8% from the annual average of 10% (BBC, 2016). This will only continue to fuel protests and outrage from citizens.

PR benefits of lifting SOE outweighed by potential risks. Leaving regional SOE in place only would negate potential PR benefits and draw attention to regional issues. Safest approach is to leave national SOE in place until they can be confident crisis has truly subsided.

The problems with government corruption and people being treated are nothing new, and the people are used to it. Unless some mass civil resistance happens, or external players choose to exploit the situation for their gains, a nationwide emergency will not happen. However, there's a lot of possibility that there might be local disturbances contained by local emergencies.

Will the state of emergency last as long as the government says it will? ...or longer? This was the first state of emergency in 25 years. This suggests a bias towards maintaining the SOE longer than originally intended, given an interest in not wishing to impose another SOE if it can be avoided.

The ruling party cannot afford to go past the 6 month limit, but the restrictions placed on physical security will remain indefinitely even after the state of emergency is lifted. The government will allow some freedom of movement and of information but will intensify their disinformation campaign to sow division and add confusion to the protest groups trying to change the status quo who have been in power since 1991. Accusations of government corruption will be met with counter-accusations of influence by outsiders for nefarious reasons within the protest groups and accusations of these groups being terrorists which has become a more common and convenient label used globally by those in power to squash legitimate dissent.

Once the state of emergency is put in place it becomes very comfortable for that government. The state of emergency most often exacerbates the protests and the protests continuation justifies the state of emergency until there is resignation by the protesters or civil war.

Protests erupted in Ethiopia on 5 August 2016 following calls by opposition groups. Protesters demanded social and political reforms including an end to human rights abuses (including government killings of civilians, mass arrests, government land seizures, and political marginalization of opposition groups). The government responded by restricting access to the Internet and attacking as well as arresting protesters. In the three days leading up to 8 August, Reuters reported that at least 90 protesters had been shot and killed by Ethiopian security forces, marking the most violent crackdown against protesters in sub-Saharan Africa since at least 75 people were killed during protests in Ethiopia's Oromia Region in November and December 2015. According to Human Rights Watch, at least 500 people are estimated to have been killed as of October 2016. The Ethiopian government denied violence being committed by the country's security forces, naming regional rivals Eritrea and Egypt as the origins for the ongoing unrest. _________________________ COMMENTS: According to the U.S. Department of State's human rights report for 2004, the Ethiopian government's human rights "remained poor; although there were improvements, serious problems remained." The report listed numerous cases where police and security forces are said to have harassed, illegally detained, tortured, and/or killed individuals, who were members of opposition groups or accused of being insurgents. Thousands of suspects remained in detention without charge, and lengthy pretrial detention continued to be a problem. Prison conditions were poor. The government often ignores citizens' privacy rights and laws regarding search warrants. Although fewer journalists have been arrested, detained, or punished in 2004 than in previous years, the government nevertheless continues to restrict freedom of the press. The government limits freedom of assembly, particularly for members of opposition groups, and security forces have used excessive force to break up demonstrations. Violence and discrimination against women continue to be problems. Female genital mutilation is widespread, although efforts to curb the practice have had some effect. The economic and sexual exploitation of children continues, as does human trafficking. Forced labor, particularly among children, is a persistent problem. Low-level government interference with labor unions continues.

@Raahul_Kumar, news that the Government of Ethiopia may cut back the length of the SOE. However the conflict between the West / Protesters and Ethiopian gov't may be ongoing for a considerable amount of time.

The Government of Ethiopia has been contemplating to cut down the duration of the state of emergency it has imposed throughout the country, Negeri Lencho (PhD) the new minister for Government Communication Affairs Office told journalists in his first presser.

The Ethiopian government seems to be under attack from outside. The government seems generally well organized and focused on growth, while the protests seem focused on governmental change, with external support. The issue may be resolved by the Ethiopian gov't realizing the vast array of international resources that may be deployed against it, as opposed to how much political control must be ceded to ensure continuity. Forecasting that it will take more than 4 months to solve this delimna.
Once a regime has a state of emergency going, it is much more enjoyable for them to keep it up as long as they can, and indeed somewhat longer. They have at least one more extension in them.

States of emergency tend to get renewed when politically expedient. Alternative scenarios include government overthrow, coup, (in which case, I suspect a new state of emergency could be declared, or existing one extended), Protests calm down peacefully and no further and state of emergency concludes as scheduled. Ends prematurely for same reason.
